titleStmt.title: An entry from the Journals of Hensley Henson

sourceDesc.bibl: Edited from the manuscripts in the custody of Durham Cathedral Library.

p.hi: The heat during the night was intense, and much rain fell. Holy Communion was celebrated in the Chapel at 8.45 a.m. Ella and I communicated. As the rain continued to fall steadily, we remained indoors, reading & writing letters. I wrote to Ernest, and to James.
In the afternoon Lord L. showed us the view from the octagonal building in the Park. At 5 p.m. there was Evensong in the Chapel. A male quartet from the Presbyterian Church in Newtownards sang "
The Sunday papers are filled with

[Bottomley], who has just been released from prison. His gross impudent countenance stares at one from the front pages, & his "revelations" of prison life fill the columns. It is no good evidence of public sanity that such a man can so move the interest of the masses. During the war this arch–swindler established a reputation for himself as "the soldier's friend", and no exposures of his frauds seem to affect the confidence of his
. Then to have been imprisoned is in these queer days a secure title to the regard & admiration of the People!
